Text.text: A value help enables users to choose one or more values from a list, or to search for and select values in a dialog view. The selected values are automatically added as input parameters in the corresponding input field.

FormattedText.htmlText: The annotation needed to support a value help is com.sap.vocabularies.Common.v1.ValueList and it's type ValueListType provides the following properties:

Panel.headerText: 1.) Value Help with a Select Control

FormattedText.htmlText: This basic value help allows a single selection from a predefined list. The annotation term Common.ValueListWithFixedValues sets the valuehelp type 'select control'.

Usage:
Select the select control menu’s arrow on the right side of the input field.
The select control opens and provides a list of possible input values for the field.
Click on a list item. The item key is entered into the input field and the select control is closed.

Feature 'Text Arrangement':
'Value Help Field 1_1' is annotated with a value list entity that has no text annotated at the corresponding property BusinessPartner, therefore the value list parameters key and description are displayed in separate columns.
'Value Help Field 1_2' is annotated with a value list entity that does have the annotations 'Text' and 'TextArrangement' set to 'TextFirst'.
Note: For the dropdown field help the text arrangement annotation is optional, as the default value is 'TextFirst'. But you can change the display format if you set the annotation ‘TextArrangement’ to another value.
If you specify a 'TextArrangement' we highly recommend to specify the same 'TextArrangement' for the property of your field as well for the corresponding property of the value help entity.

Panel.headerText: 2.) Value Help with a Dialog Control

FormattedText.htmlText:
This basic value help allows a single selection from a value help dialog.
This is the default value help type if there is no annotation Common.ValueListWithFixedValues for the field.

Usage:
Select the icon on the right side of the input field. The dialog opens and provides a list of possible input values in table format.
Click on a table line. The item key is entered into the input field and the dialog is closed.

'Value Help Field 2_1' is annotated with a value list entity that has no text arrangement annotated to the corresponding property BusinessPartner, therefore the value list parameters key and description are displayed in separate columns.
'Value Help Field 2_2' is annotated with a value list entity that does have a annotation 'Text' and 'TextArrangement' set to 'TextFirst' at the correponding property BusinessPartner. Therefore the value list parameters key and description are displayed in one column.

Note: In contrast to the dropdown field help (Example 1, Value Help Field 1_2), the text arrangement annotation is NOT optional.
You can change the display format if you set the annotation 'TextArrangement' to another value.

Feature 'Typeahead':
By default, typeahead is active if an input field is annotated with Common.ValueList. When you start typing, a table opens containing those items from the value list entity which fits to the “searchterm” you entered. The backend might also consider properties which are not visible in the value help but be a part of the value help entity. You can then select one of the table rows to specify the input value.
For field 'Value Help Field 2_1' the visible table columns are determined with annotation UI.Importance: High at the related property in the value list definition of the field.
Typeahead can be deactivated by annotating the value list entity with Capabilities.SearchRestrictions.Searchable : false.
Therefore, the typeahead in 'Value Help Field 2_3' is not available since the associated entity 'BusinessPartnerAddress3' was annotated with Capabilities.SearchRestrictions.Searchable: false.

This example demonstrates the validation feature for a field with a value help.
'Value Help Field 3_1' is annotated with Common.ValueListForValidation. Therefore, the input value is validated against the data from the value list entity when leaving the field.

Usage:
Enter any value in 'Value Help Field 3_1' and either use the tab key or the mouse to remove the focus from the field.
If the value entered is not found in the value help data set, the field is marked with a red frame. If you now set the foucs back to the field you see a error message below the field, indicating that the value does not exist.
Note: In the Select Control field help (Example 1, Value Help Field 1_1 and Value Help Field 1_2), validation is done by default, so the annotation Common.ValueListForValidation is NOT necessary.

Some scenarios require different value help dialogs based on a context. This context is determined by a property other than the annotated property.
You can use the annotation term Common.ValueListRelevantQualifiers to configure the behavior of the value help if you are using more than one value list.

Usage:
Select the icon on the right side of the input field 'Value Help Field 4_2'. A dialog opens. Close the value help.
Select item 17100001 or 17100006 from the dropdown value list of the field 'Value Help Field 4_1'.
When you now open the value help for field 'Value Help Field 4_2' again you will notice that now the content visualization of the value help is different than before.
Select another item (not the same as before) from the dropdown value list of the field 'Value Help Field 4_1'. Now the value help of field 'Value Help Field 4_2' displays the initial variant again.

Some scenarios require more than one value help.
You can use a collection of ValueList annotations to select a value help variant from a dropdown list in a value help dialog.

Usage:
Select the icon on the right side of the input field 'Value Help Field 5_1'. A dialog opens.
Select the dropdown menu’s arrow at the top of the dialog. Select an item from the dropdown list to change the value help in the dialog.

Panel.headerText: 6.) Control the Content of the Dropdown List if You’re Using Multiple Value Help Dialogs

FormattedText.htmlText:
Some scenarios require more than one multiple value help compilation.
Combine techniques from examples 3 and 4 above to define the content of the value help dropdown list based on a context. This context is determined by a property other than the annotated property.
You can use the annotation term Common.ValueListRelevantQualifiers to group collections of value lists in distinct compilations that are presented dependent on the value of another field.

Usage:
Select the dropdown menu’s arrow on the right side of the input field 'Value Help Field 6_1' and select item '17100001'.
Now open the value help of the input field 'Value Help Field 6_2'. When you now open the value help again you will notice that the value help compilation in the dropdown list consists of 'Business Partner Address 2' and 'Business Partner Address 3'.

Open the value help of input field 'Value Help Field 6_1' again and select item '17100006'.
Now the value help compilation of input field 'Value Help Field 6_2' consists of 'Business Partner Address 3' and 'Business Partner Address 4'.

If you select any other value in input field 'Value Help Field 6_1', this results in the default value help 'Business Partner Address' being automatically selected for 'Value Help Field 6_2'.

Panel.headerText: 7.) Mapping of In/Out Parameters in the ValueList Annotation

FormattedText.htmlText: This example provides information about the structure of the ValueList annotation and how the In/Out mappings there allow linking between fields of the main entity and fields of the value help entity.

Usage:

1. Out-Mapping
Open the value help dialog of the input field 'Account ID' and select an item from the value list. The dialog is closed and the key of the selected item is displayed in the input field.
Note that the name of the selected item is also displayed in the field 'Account Full Name'.
This is because of the annotation ValueListParameterOut
...
						$Type            : 'Common.ValueListParameterOut',

						LocalDataProperty: valueHelpField7_2,

						ValueListProperty: 'FullName',
...
in the ValueList definition for the field valueHelpField7_1.
The parameters 'CityName' and 'Country' are annotated with ValueListParameterDisplayOnly and are therefore only displayed as a column in the table of the value list dialog.

2. In-Mapping
Open the value help dialog of the input field 'Account ID' and select item 'ACC-5'. Then open the value help of the input field 'Business Partner'.
Note that the value help table is now filtered with the value of the selected account.
Press the 'Show Filters' button in the table header. Note that the filter field 'Account' is added to the filter bar and is prefilled with the selected account from the field valueHelpField7_1.
This is because of the annotation ValueListParameterIn
...
						$Type            : 'Common.ValueListParameterIn',

						LocalDataProperty: valueHelpField7_1,

						ValueListProperty: 'Account',
...
in the ValueList definition for the field valueHelpField7_3.

3. In/Out-Mapping
Open the value help dialog of the input field 'Partner Function'.
Press the 'Show Filters' button in the table header.
Note that the filter fields 'Account' and 'BusinessPartner' are added to the filter bar and are prefilled with the corresponding values.
In addition, the column 'Business Partner' is added to the value list table.
This is because of the following annotations in the ValueList definition for field valueHelpField7_4:

...
							$Type            : 'Common.ValueListParameterIn',

							LocalDataProperty: valueHelpField7_1,

							ValueListProperty: 'Account',
...

and

...
							$Type            : 'Common.ValueListParameterInOut',

							LocalDataProperty: valueHelpField7_3,

							ValueListProperty: 'BusinessPartner',
...

Clear the filter field 'Business Partner' and press the 'Go' button. Select the row with business partner '17100007'.
Note that after the value help is closed the value in the field 'Business Partner' has changed to '17100007' and the field 'Partner Function' is filled with 'Ship-to Party'.

Panel.headerText: 8.) Side Effect on a Value Help Selection to Update the Value Help Collection

FormattedText.htmlText: This section provides information about invoking a side effect to update the value help collection if the content of the collection has changed.
This use case is demonstrated in chapter 'Usage of Side Effects' in item '8.) Side Effect for Refreshing Data of an Entity & for Invalidating a Cached Value Help'.
